bonds: A family member is in trouble
A mentor taught me everything I know
I owe everything to my patron
Someone stole something precious from me
I am haunted by a past failure
I would die for my homeland
I seek to recover a lost artifact
A loved one waits for my return
I was framed for a crime I didn't commit
I am searching for a sibling
flaws: A powerful enemy seeks my destruction
I can't resist a pretty face
I am too greedy for my own good
I am inflexible in my thinking
I am easily distracted by shiny objects
I will do anything for power
I hold grudges and never forgive
appearance: Flamboyant, outlandish, formal, or ragged clothes
Unusual eye color (or two different colors)
Bald, or braided beard or hair
talents: Expert dart thrower and rock skipper
Skilled actor and master of disguise
highAbility: Strength — powerful, brawny, hard as nails
secrets: In disguise, concealing identity or appearance
Planning, executing, or covering up a crime
Threatened with harm unless they do something
Under magical compulsion (e.g. Geas or curse)
Seriously ill or in terrible pain
Feels responsible for someone's death or ill fortune
On the brink of financial ruin
Desperately lonely or harboring unrequited passion

weather.condition: 1d4 degrees colder than normal; 1d4 degrees hotter in a hot climate
1d4 × 5 degrees colder than normal; 1d4 × 5 degrees hotter in a hot climate
Precipitation (rain, snow, or sandstorm in desert)

plotHooks: A local merchant's shipment has gone missing on the road
Strange lights appear in the abandoned keep at night
Children are going missing from the village
A dragon has been spotted flying over the mountains
An ancient tomb has been uncovered by recent storms
The harvest is failing and the druids blame dark magic
A traveling bard tells tales of a lost city of gold
The local lord's heir has been kidnapped
Undead are rising from the old cemetery
A mysterious plague is spreading through the district
A portal to another plane has opened in the forest
The thieves' guild wants to hire the party for a heist
An oracle predicts doom unless heroes intervene
Pirates are blockading the harbor
A cult is gaining influence in the city
An earthquake has revealed a passage to the Underdark
A bounty has been posted for a notorious outlaw
The local temple has been desecrated
A powerful artifact has been stolen from the museum
Refugees are flooding in from a war-torn neighboring land

entries.quirk: Abandoned after internal strife devastated its population
Abandoned because the site was cursed by a god or other powerful entity
Abandoned by its original creators when a plague spread through the dungeon
Amazingly well preserved ancient city inside a dome encased in volcanic ash, submerged underwater, or entombed in desert sands
Built as a fortress guarding a mountain pass
Built as a maze, either to protect treasure from intruders or as a gauntlet where prisoners were hunted by monsters
Built as a stronghold but abandoned after it fell to invaders
Built as a treasure vault to protect powerful magic items and great wealth
Built atop a cloud
Built beneath a city in catacombs or sewers
Built beneath or on top of a mesa or several connected mesas
Built by a religious group to serve as a temple and linked to the energy of other planes of existence
Built by dwarves and decorated with enormous dwarven faces that have been defaced by its current inhabitants
Built in a volcano
Built in or among the branches of a tree
Built to house a planar portal but abandoned when creatures or energy from the other side of the portal seeped into the dungeon
Carved into a meteorite (before or after it fell to earth)
Carved into a sheer cliff face
Caverns carved by a beholder's disintegration eye ray, with unnaturally smooth walls and vertical shafts connecting different levels
Contains something that led to the downfall of its creators or inhabitants
Dug as a burrow by a monster that might still live inside
Entrance concealed behind a waterfall
Floating on the sea
Intended as a death trap to eliminate any creature that enters, perhaps to guard treasure or to harvest souls for a necromantic rite
Intended as a tomb
Long known as the site of a great miracle or another auspicious event
Made by amphibious creatures (such as kuo-toa or aboleths), using water to protect the innermost reaches from air-breathing intruders
Made by a powerful spellcaster (perhaps a lich) as a site for magical research and experimentation
Made by giants at a vast scale
Natural caverns featuring a range of strikingly beautiful rock and crystal formations
On an island in an underground sea
On the back of a Gargantuan creature
Originally constructed as a mine but abandoned when tunnels connected to dangerous Underdark tunnels
Secreted away in a demiplane or in a pocket dimension
Slowly abandoned as its creators died out or migrated away
Transformed by multiple events or disasters over the course of centuries

entries.name: Perilous
entries.description: The area is dangerously worn and prone to collapse. Any impacts or damage to the structure, including from spells and other areas of effect, have a 50 percent chance of causing a collapse.

entries.name: Crumbling
entries.description: Areas within the dungeon section are choked with rubble and have a 50 percent chance of being Difficult Terrain. Half Cover and hiding places are plentiful.

entries.name: Neglected
entries.description: One dungeon hazard — such as brown mold, green slime, or yellow mold — is abundant.

entries.name: Abandoned
entries.description: Most of the dungeon is deserted. Dexterity (Stealth) checks have Disadvantage because any sounds stand out as unusual.

entries.name: Secure
entries.description: Ability checks made to break down doors, open locks, or carry out similar activities have Disadvantage.

entries.name: Thriving
entries.description: The dungeon is heavily populated. Any loud noises draw the attention of nearby creatures.

travelTerrain.maxPaceNote: Appropriate equipment (such as skis) is necessary to keep up a Fast pace in Arctic terrain.
Characters' rate of travel while waterborne depends on the vehicle carrying them.

environmentalEffects.name: Dead Magic Zone
environmentalEffects.description: An area where the fabric of magic is torn. The effect is the same as the Antimagic Field spell, except that it is permanent and typically covers an area no more than 300 feet in diameter.

environmentalEffects.name: Deep Water
environmentalEffects.description: Swimming through deep water (more than 100 feet deep) presents additional challenges because of the water's pressure and cold temperature. After each hour of swimming in deep water, a creature that lacks a Swim Speed must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Exhaustion level.

environmentalEffects.name: Extreme Cold
environmentalEffects.description: When the temperature is 0 degrees Fahrenheit or lower, a creature exposed to the extreme cold must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw at the end of each hour or gain 1 Exhaustion level. Creatures that have Resistance or Immunity to Cold damage automatically succeed on the save.
environmentalEffects.immunity: Resistance or Immunity to Cold damage

environmentalEffects.name: Extreme Heat
environmentalEffects.description: When the temperature is 100 degrees Fahrenheit or higher, a creature exposed to the extreme heat and without access to drinkable water must succeed on a Constitution saving throw at the end of each hour or gain 1 Exhaustion level. The DC is 5 for the first hour and increases by 1 for each additional hour. Creatures wearing Medium or Heavy armor have Disadvantage on the save. Creatures that have Resistance or Immunity to Fire damage automatically succeed on the save.
environmentalEffects.dcNote: Increases by 1 for each additional hour
environmentalEffects.immunity: Resistance or Immunity to Fire damage

environmentalEffects.name: Frigid Water
environmentalEffects.description: A creature can be immersed in frigid water for a number of minutes equal to its Constitution score before suffering any ill effects. Each additional minute spent in frigid water requires the creature to succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 Exhaustion level. Creatures with Resistance or Immunity to Cold damage automatically succeed on the save, as do creatures that are naturally adapted to living in ice-cold water.
environmentalEffects.immunity: Resistance or Immunity to Cold damage

environmentalEffects.name: Heavy Precipitation
environmentalEffects.description: Everything within an area of heavy rain or heavy snowfall is Lightly Obscured, and creatures in the area have Disadvantage on all Wisdom (Perception) checks. Heavy rain also extinguishes open flames.

environmentalEffects.name: High Altitude
environmentalEffects.description: Traveling at altitudes of 10,000 feet or higher above sea level is taxing for most creatures because of the reduced amount of oxygen in the air. Each hour a creature spends traveling at high altitude counts as 2 hours for the purpose of determining how long that creature can travel. Creatures can become acclimated to a high altitude by spending 30 days or more at this elevation. Creatures can't become acclimated to elevations above 20,000 feet unless they are native to such environments.

environmentalEffects.name: Slippery Ice
environmentalEffects.description: Slippery ice is Difficult Terrain. A creature that moves onto slippery ice for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or have the Prone condition.

environmentalEffects.name: Strong Wind
environmentalEffects.description: Strong wind imposes Disadvantage on ranged attack rolls with weapons. It also extinguishes open flames and disperses fog. A flying creature in a strong wind must land at the end of its turn or fall. A strong wind in a desert can create a sandstorm that imposes Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks.

environmentalEffects.name: Thin Ice
environmentalEffects.description: Thin ice has a weight tolerance of 3d10 × 10 pounds per 10-foot-square area. Whenever the total weight on an area of thin ice exceeds its tolerance, the ice in that area breaks. All creatures on broken ice fall through. Below the ice is frigid water.

environmentalEffects.name: Wild Magic Zone
environmentalEffects.description: A past magical disaster or uncontrolled surge of power in a particular place can cause the fabric of magic to unravel, creating a wild magic zone. In such an area, which is typically no more than 300 feet in diameter, magic behaves unpredictably. Whenever a creature expends a spell slot to cast a spell in a wild magic zone, roll 1d20. If you roll a 20, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a magical effect.
conditions: Wild Magic Surge on roll of 20

hazards.name: Brown Mold
hazards.description: Brown mold resembles a furry, light-brown carpet. This fungus feeds on warmth, drawing heat from anything around itself. One patch covers a 10-foot square, and the temperature within 30 feet of it is always frigid.
hazards.trigger: Entering a space within 5 feet of the mold for the first time on a turn or starting a turn there
hazards.detection: Visible as a furry, light-brown carpet. Temperature within 30 feet is frigid.
hazards.countermeasures: Immune to Fire damage (fire causes it to expand). Destroyed instantly by any Cold damage.

hazards.name: Fireball Fungus
hazards.description: A Small, inanimate mushroom that can grow anywhere fungi are found in abundance. Its luminous, orange cap sheds Bright Light in a 15-foot radius and Dim Light for an additional 15 feet.
hazards.trigger: Dropping to 0 Hit Points (AC 10, HP 6, Immune to Psychic damage)
hazards.detection: Luminous orange cap sheds Bright Light in a 15-foot radius.
hazards.countermeasures: Has AC 10 and HP 6. Can be destroyed from a distance. Chain-detonates with other fireball fungi.

hazards.name: Green Slime
hazards.description: Acidic green slime devours flesh, organic material, and metal on contact. Bright green, wet, and sticky, it clings to walls, floors, and ceilings in patches.
hazards.trigger: Drops from walls and ceilings when it detects movement below (Blindsight 30 ft.). DC 10 Dexterity save to avoid if aware.
hazards.damage: 5 (1d10) Acid per turn on contact. 11 (2d10) Acid per round against wood or metal.
hazards.detection: Bright green, wet, and sticky. Clings to surfaces. Has Blindsight 30 ft.
hazards.countermeasures: Scraped off as an action (nonmagical metal/wood tools destroyed). Direct sunlight or any Cold, Fire, or Radiant damage destroys it.

hazards.name: Inferno
hazards.description: Whenever an uncontrolled fire spreads, it can create an inferno that quickly engulfs creatures, objects, and vegetation.
hazards.trigger: Entering the inferno for the first time on a turn or starting a turn there
hazards.damage: 22 (4d10) Fire; creature is burning. Also damages objects not worn/carried.
hazards.detection: Visible fire consisting of at least four contiguous 10-foot Cubes.
hazards.countermeasures: Each 10-foot Cube can be doused with 10 gallons of water. Burns itself out after 1d10 minutes if deprived of fuel. Strong wind causes growth (1d4 additional Cubes).

hazards.name: Poisonous Gas
hazards.description: Poisonous gas is usually encountered in an enclosed space, such as a sewer or sealed tomb. The transparent gas carries a foul odor and fills up to ten 10-foot Cubes.
hazards.trigger: Entering gas for the first time on a turn or starting a turn there
hazards.detection: Transparent but carries a foul odor.
hazards.countermeasures: Dispersed by a strong wind for 1 minute. Higher levels: DC 14/2d10 (5–10), DC 16/4d10 (11–16), DC 18/10d10 (17–20).

hazards.name: Quicksand Pit
hazards.description: A quicksand pit is 10 feet deep and covers the ground in a 10-foot square.
hazards.trigger: Entering the area; creature sinks 1d4 + 1 feet and is Restrained
conditions: Blinded and Total Cover if fully submerged
hazards.detection: Appears as normal ground; may require a Perception check.
hazards.countermeasures: Action to escape (DC 10 + feet sunk). Another creature within reach can pull the victim out (DC 5 + feet sunk). Higher levels: 15 ft. deep/1d6 (5–10), 20 ft./1d8 (11–16), 30 ft./1d10 (17–20).

hazards.name: Razorvine
hazards.description: Razorvine is a plant that grows in wild tangles and hedges. It also clings to the sides of buildings and other surfaces as ivy does.
hazards.trigger: Coming into contact with razorvine for the first time on a turn
hazards.detection: Visible as thorny vine tangles. A 10-foot wall/hedge has AC 11, HP 25; Immune to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Psychic damage.
hazards.countermeasures: Can be destroyed (AC 11, HP 25). Immune to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Psychic damage.

hazards.name: River Styx
hazards.description: The River Styx courses through the Lower Planes. Tasting or touching its waters can shatter a creature's intellect and personality, as well as strip away its memories.
hazards.trigger: Drinking from, entering, or starting a turn in the River Styx
conditions: Can't cast spells or take the Magic action for 30 days
hazards.detection: Known planar feature of the Lower Planes.
hazards.countermeasures: Greater Restoration, Heal, or Wish spell removes the effect. If not removed after 30 days, becomes permanent (only Wish or divine intervention). Water loses potency after 24 hours.

hazards.name: Rockslide
hazards.description: When a rockslide occurs, every creature in its path is struck by tumbling rocks and debris.
hazards.trigger: Being in the path of the rockslide
conditions: Restrained and Total Cover if buried
hazards.detection: May be preceded by rumbling sounds or loose rocks.
hazards.countermeasures: Buried creatures can escape with DC 15 Strength (Athletics); failure causes 1 Exhaustion level. Another creature can spend 1 minute freeing a buried creature. Higher levels: 4d10 (5–10), 10d10 (11–16), 18d10 (17–20).

hazards.name: Vicious Vine
hazards.description: Vicious vines are animated by magic. They often cling to doorways, archways, walls, and statuary. Until a vicious vine moves, there's nothing to distinguish it from an inanimate vine.
hazards.trigger: Entering a space within 5 feet or starting a turn there
hazards.detection: Indistinguishable from an inanimate vine until it moves. AC 11, HP 16; Immune to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Psychic damage.
hazards.countermeasures: Speak with Plants + DC 10 Charisma (Persuasion) to release. Can grapple only one creature. Higher levels: DC 14/2d10 (5–10), DC 16/4d10 (11–16), DC 18/10d10 (17–20).

hazards.name: Webs
hazards.description: Giant spiders weave thick, sticky webs across passages and at the bottom of pits to snare prey. These web-filled areas are Difficult Terrain.
hazards.trigger: Entering a web-filled area for the first time on a turn or starting a turn there
hazards.detection: Visible as thick, sticky webbing. Each 10-foot Cube has AC 10, HP 15.
hazards.countermeasures: Escape as an action with DC 12 Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics). Webs have Vulnerability to Fire; Immunity to Piercing, Poison, and Psychic damage.

hazards.name: Yellow Mold
hazards.description: Yellow mold grows in dark places, and one patch covers a 5-foot square. If touched, the mold ejects a cloud of spores that fills a 10-foot Cube.
hazards.trigger: Touching the mold causes a spore cloud in a 10-foot Cube
hazards.damage: 11 (2d10) Poison, plus 5 (1d10) Poison at start of each turn while Poisoned
hazards.detection: Visible as yellow growth in dark places, covering a 5-foot square.
hazards.countermeasures: Direct sunlight or any amount of Fire damage destroys a patch. Poisoned creature repeats save at end of each turn.

poisons.name: Assassin's Blood
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature takes damage and has the Poisoned condition for 24 hours. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

poisons.name: Burnt Othur Fumes
poisons.damage: 10 (3d6) Poison initial, then 3 (1d6) Poison on each failed repeat save
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature takes 10 (3d6) Poison damage and must repeat the save at the start of each of its turns. On each successive failed save, the creature takes 3 (1d6) Poison damage. After three successful saves, the poison ends.

poisons.name: Carrion Crawler Mucus
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature has the Poisoned condition for 1 minute. The creature also has the Paralyzed condition while Poisoned in this way. The creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

poisons.name: Lolth's Sting
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature has the Poisoned condition for 1 hour. If the creature fails the save by 5 or more, it also has the Unconscious condition while Poisoned. The creature wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

poisons.name: Essence of Ether
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature has the Poisoned condition for 8 hours. The creature also has the Unconscious condition while Poisoned. The creature wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

poisons.name: Malice
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature has the Poisoned condition for 1 hour. The creature also has the Blinded condition while Poisoned in this way.

poisons.name: Midnight Tears
poisons.effects: A creature that ingests Midnight Tears suffers no effect until the stroke of midnight. Any effect that ends the Poisoned condition neutralizes this poison. If the poison hasn't been neutralized before midnight, the creature makes a save, taking damage on a failure or half on a success.

poisons.name: Oil of Taggit
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature has the Poisoned condition for 24 hours. The creature also has the Unconscious condition while Poisoned. It wakes up if it takes damage.

poisons.name: Pale Tincture
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature takes 3 (1d6) Poison damage and has the Poisoned condition. The Poisoned creature repeats the save every 24 hours, taking 3 (1d6) Poison damage on a failed save. The damage can't be healed while the creature remains Poisoned. After seven successful saves, the creature is no longer Poisoned.

poisons.name: Purple Worm Poison
poisons.effects: The creature makes a save, taking 35 (10d6) Poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

poisons.name: Serpent Venom
poisons.effects: The creature must succeed on a save, taking 10 (3d6) Poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

poisons.name: Torpor
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature has the Poisoned condition for 4d6 hours. The creature's Speed is halved while Poisoned in this way.

poisons.name: Truth Serum
poisons.effects: On a failed save, the creature has the Poisoned condition for 1 hour. The Poisoned creature can't knowingly communicate a lie.

poisons.name: Wyvern Poison
poisons.effects: The creature makes a save, taking 24 (7d6) Poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.
